general: This law creates a new organization to help people with their finances, including those who are struggling with debt. It also provides funds for debt advice in different parts of the UK, and gives the government the power to stop companies from sending unwanted advertisements about financial products and services. Additionally, the law regulates businesses that help people make claims for things like compensation or refunds.

series.short: "Establishment of Single Financial Guidance Body for Consumer Financial Support"
series.text:
* The Single Financial Guidance Body will be established to provide financial guidance to consumers.
* The Single Financial Guidance Body will take over the functions of the Consumer Financial Education Body and the Pensions Advisory Service Limited.
* Regulations can be made to change the name of the Single Financial Guidance Body and to make incidental, supplementary and consequential provisions.
* The power to make regulations is exercisable by statutory instrument and can be annulled by a resolution of either House of Parliament.
* Schemes for the transfer of staff, property, rights and liabilities from the Secretary of State, the Pensions Advisory Service Limited and the Consumer Financial Education Body to the Single Financial Guidance Body and the devolved authorities will be made.

series.short: "Financial Guidance and Support for the Public: A Single Body for Information and Advice"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Financial Guidance and Claims Act 2018 sets up a single financial guidance body to provide information, guidance, and advice to the public on financial matters.
* Simplified point 2: The single financial guidance body has several functions, including providing pensions guidance, debt advice, money guidance, and consumer protection, and developing and coordinating a national strategy to improve financial capability.
* Simplified point 3: The single financial guidance body must have regard to its objectives and functions when exercising its powers, and must provide information, guidance, and advice to the public free of charge.
* Simplified point 4: The single financial guidance body may delegate its functions to delivery partner organizations, and must have regard to guidance and directions given to it by the Secretary of State.

series.short: "Financial Guidance Standards: Protecting Consumer Interests"
series.text:
* The Single Financial Guidance Body (SFGB) sets standards for those providing financial guidance, including pension, debt, and money guidance. These standards must be approved by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA).
* The SFGB monitors and enforces compliance with these standards, and the FCA reviews them periodically to ensure they remain appropriate and effective.
* The purpose of these standards is to protect consumers and ensure they receive accurate and unbiased financial guidance.

series.short: "UK Government Funding for Single Financial Guidance Body"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government can provide funding to establish a single financial guidance body through grants or loans.
* Simplified point 2: The government can also provide financial assistance to the single financial guidance body for carrying out its functions.
* Simplified point 3: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) can make rules to recover expenses incurred by the Secretary of State related to the establishment and operation of the single financial guidance body.
* Simplified point 4: The FCA can impose levies on authorized persons, electronic money issuers, or payment service providers to recover expenses incurred by the Secretary of State.
* Simplified point 5: The Secretary of State can notify the FCA of matters to be taken into account when deciding whether or not to give consent to the rules made under section 137SA of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000.

series.short: "UK Government's Debt Advice Services Funding Mechanism"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The UK government can levy fees on financial institutions to cover the costs of providing debt advice services in Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.
* Simplified point 2: The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) is responsible for collecting these fees from authorized financial institutions and must use the funds to cover the expenses incurred by the devolved authorities in providing debt advice.
* Simplified point 3: The FCA must consult the Treasury before making rules to impose levies, and the Treasury may specify matters that will be taken into account when deciding whether or not to give consent to the rules.
* Simplified point 4: If the Treasury notifies the FCA of an amount of expenses expected to be incurred, but the actual expenses incurred are less than the amount notified, the FCA must pay the difference back to the Treasury.

series.short: "Financial Regulation Offenses: Legal Consequences for Unauthorized Advice"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The law states it's an offense to pretend to provide financial guidance on behalf of the Single Financial Guidance Body without proper authorization.
* Simplified point 2: If someone is found guilty of this offense, they could face up to 51 weeks in prison in England and Wales, 12 months in Scotland, or 6 months in Northern Ireland, along with a possible fine.
* Simplified point 3: This law applies to individuals and companies, and officers of these entities can also be held responsible for any offenses committed by the company.
* Simplified point 4: Partnerships and unincorporated associations can also be held accountable for offenses committed by their members or officers.
* Simplified point 5: Proceedings for these offenses must be brought against the entity in question, whether it's a partnership, unincorporated association, or body corporate, using rules of court related to serving documents.

series.short: "Financial Information Sharing and Disclosure Regulations"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Single Financial Guidance Body can share information with various organizations such as the Secretary of State, FCA, and devolved authorities for the purpose of exercising their functions related to debt advice and consumer protection.
* Simplified point 2: The Single Financial Guidance Body must disclose information to the Secretary of State and FCA upon request, and it cannot disclose information that would contravene data protection laws or be prohibited by other legislations.

series.short: "UK Government Updates Financial Guidance Laws for Pension Schemes"
series.text:
* The UK government is making changes to the laws regarding financial guidance and claims.
* One of these changes involves adding new sections to the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 and the Pension Schemes Act 1993.
* These new sections will require personal pension schemes to refer members to guidance before allowing them to transfer rights or receive benefits.
* The goal of this change is to ensure that individuals understand their options and make informed decisions when dealing with their pensions.
* The change will also require trustees or managers of pension schemes to provide explanations of the nature and purpose of pensions guidance.
* Additionally, the change will mandate that individuals be referred to appropriate pensions guidance before proceeding with applications to transfer rights or receive benefits.
* The regulations may specify what constitutes appropriate pensions guidance and provide for exceptions to the duties in specified cases.
* The change will also require the FCA to make general rules requiring specified authorized persons to provide information about the availability of financial guidance to certain descriptions of persons.
* Before publishing drafts of any rules, the FCA must consult with the Secretary of State, the Treasury, and the single financial guidance body.

series.short: "Government Regulation of Unsolicited Direct Marketing: Protecting Consumers from Spam"
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The government can make laws to stop companies from sending unwanted emails, texts, or letters about financial products like pensions.

* Simplified point 4: The laws can also say how the Information Commissioner and OFCOM (a communications regulator) should enforce the rules.
* Simplified point 5: The government must review every year if more laws are needed to protect people from unsolicited direct marketing.

series.short: The Financial Guidance and Claims Act 2018: Regulatory Shift from MoJ to FCA
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Financial Guidance and Claims Act 2018 transfers the regulation of claims management services from the Ministry of Justice to the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA).
* Simplified point 2: The act defines "regulated claims management activity" as an activity of a specified kind, related to claims management services, carried out in Great Britain. It also provides for the FCA to make orders regarding the circumstances in which a person is or is not to be treated as carrying on such activities in Great Britain.

series.short: "Regulatory Oversight of Claims Management Companies: Protecting Consumers from Excessive Fees"
series.text:

* Simplified point 3: The FCA has the power to prohibit claims management companies from entering into certain types of agreements or imposing specific charges that are deemed excessive.
* Simplified point 4: If a company violates these rules, the FCA can make the agreement or obligation to pay the charge unenforceable, provide for the recovery of amounts paid under the agreement, or require the payment of compensation for any losses incurred.

series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Financial Guidance and Claims Act 2018 sets a fee cap of 20% for claims management services related to Payment Protection Insurance (PPI) claims. This means that claims management companies cannot charge more than 20% of the amount recovered for the claimant.

* Simplified point 3: The legislation defines "regulated claims management services" and "regulated claims management activity" and specifies that certain activities are excluded from the definition of regulated claims management services.
* Simplified point 4: The legislation also defines "PPI claim" and "amount recovered for the claimant" for the purposes of the fee cap.
* Simplified point 5: The legislation provides that the FCA may make orders specifying kinds of activities as regulated activities within the meaning of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000.

The Act creates a single financial guidance body to provide information and guidance to consumers on financial matters. This body will offer pensions guidance, debt advice, money guidance, and consumer protection. They will also develop and coordinate a national strategy to improve financial capability.
It's important to note that pretending to provide financial guidance on behalf of the Single Financial Guidance Body without proper authorization is illegal and could result in up to 51 weeks in prison in England and Wales, 12 months in Scotland, or 6 months in Northern Ireland, along with a possible fine.
Additionally, the Act regulates claims management services related to Payment Protection Insurance (PPI) claims. It places a fee cap of 20% on these services and restricts charges for PPI claims management services. Some activities are excluded from the definition of regulated claims management services.
